Appendix 3           
 
 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) of the Kyrgyz Republic has 
requested ADB for a project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) to identify, formulate,  
and prepare a project of Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation1 Corridors 1 and 3 
Connector Road.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The  main  outcome  of  the  PPTA  is  to  prepare  a  feasibility  study  suitable  for  ADB 
financing. The PPTA will cover the preparation of the feasibility study of the road sections to be 
rehabilitated. They are (i) from Balykchy village to kilometer marker 43, approximately 43 km;  
(ii) from Kochkor village to Jyldyz village, approximately 119 km; and (iii) from Aral village to 
CAREC 3 road corridor (via Suusamyr valley), approximately 91 km. The project scope also 
includes soft components to tackle sector-wide issues. Agreement needs to be reached with the 
government  on  the  details.  It  may  include  support  to  (i)  improve  efficiency  of  road  asset 
management,  (ii)  assist  the  government  with  institutional  reforms  in  transport  sector,  
(iii)  introduce  performance-based  maintenance  contracts,  and  (iv)  improve  road  safety.  
The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table A3.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.1 million equivalent, of which $1 million equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-V).  
The government will provide in-kind counterpart support, such as counterpart staff, and other  
in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

Appendix 3 
 
D.  Consulting Services 
5.  For  the  PPTA,  a  consulting  firm  will  be  recruited  using  the  quality-and  cost-based 
selection procedure, with a simplified technical proposal and a 90:10 proportion of quality to 
cost.  90:10  is  required  due  to  the  technical  knowledge  required  in  preparing  a  PPTA.  
The  services  will  be  implemented  over  about  14  calendar  months  and  will  require  about  
27 international person-months and 34 national person-months.2 ADB will select and engage 
the  consulting  firm  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  
(2013, as amended from time to time). Table A3.3 shows the summary of consulting services 
requirements; see Supplementary Appendix for the detailed terms of reference.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
6.  MOTC  will  be  the  executing  agency  of  the  PPTA  and  its  Investment  Project 
Implementation Group (IPIG) will be the implementing agency. A project coordinator will be 
appointed  for  the  PPTA  to  monitor  the  day-to-day  progress  and  prepare  the  necessary 
documents and reports. MOTC will provide (i) counterpart staff, who will work closely with the 
consultants; and (ii) project-related data and information for the consultant to carry out the works 
and  deliver  the  outputs.  TA  funds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The tentative TA 
processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A3.4.
